Key Arguments: The legislation threatens free speech, which is essential to democracy.
Determining what constitutes misinformation or disinformation is subjective.
The enforcement of these rules could lead to biased restrictions on free speech.
Historical examples show that controlling information can lead to disastrous outcomes.
Exempting government, educational institutions, and mainstream media from the laws could lead to loss of trust.
Main Themes: Subjectivity and bias in defining misinformation
Notable Quotes: Free speech is essential to democracy and that any attempt to limit free speech by designating certain ideas as misinformation, disinformation or malinformation is a direct attempt to control the communications of all Australians.
As we have seen throughout history, controlling information to enforce orthodoxies, initially with the best of intentions, has resulted in disastrous outcomes.
We urge our political leaders to abandon this dangerous and ill advised proposal.
